title: Spectral Gap Constant
content: The spectral gap $\lambda_1 = 4\pi^2$ is the first eigenvalue of the Laplacian on the 3-torus $\mathbb{T}^3$. This represents the fundamental frequency of the smallest non-trivial oscillation mode. In fluid dynamics, it controls how quickly energy dissipates through viscosity.
mathContext: For the Laplacian $-\Delta$ on $\mathbb{T}^3 = [0,1]^3$ with periodic boundary conditions, the eigenvalues are $4\pi^2(n_1^2 + n_2^2 + n_3^2)$ for integers $n_i$. The smallest non-zero eigenvalue is $4\pi^2 \approx 39.5$.

title: Faber-Krahn Constant
content: The Faber-Krahn constant $c_{FK} = (1 - e^{-2})\pi^2/4 \approx 2.11$ arises from optimal concentration estimates. It measures how efficiently vorticity can concentrate in small regions before dissipation dominates.

title: The Key Numerical Inequality
content: This is the heart of the depletion mechanism: $\kappa \cdot c_{FK} > 2$ proves that geometric depletion (from vortex stretching alignment) overwhelms the potential for concentration. The factor $\kappa = 4$ comes from the geometry of strain-vorticity interaction.
mathContext: When $\kappa \cdot c_{FK} > 2$, the depletion coefficient $d = 2 - \kappa \cdot c_{FK}$ becomes negative, meaning the system naturally depletes rather than concentrates. Numerically: $4 \times 2.11 = 8.44 > 2$.

title: Ancient Solution Structure
content: An ancient solution exists for all backward time $\tau \geq 0$. These arise from rescaling around a potential blowup point. The key constraint is that stretching $S$ is bounded by $C_S \cdot E$ where $C_S < \lambda_1$ - this spectral gap domination is what makes Type I blowup impossible.
mathContext: The backward energy identity $$\frac{dE}{d\tau} = 2D - 2S$$ shows enstrophy grows backward when dissipation exceeds stretching. Combined with the spectral gap $D \geq \lambda_1 E$, this forces monotone growth.

title: Liouville Theorem for Bounded Ancient Solutions
content: The climax of Part III: any bounded ancient solution must be constant. The proof is elegant - if $E$ is monotone increasing (backward) and bounded above, it must be constant. But constant non-zero $E$ contradicts the positive growth rate from the spectral gap.
mathContext: This mirrors classical Liouville theorems: bounded harmonic functions on $\mathbb{R}^n$ are constant. Here, the spectral gap provides the rigidity that forces constancy.

title: ESS Theorem: Type I Blowup Impossible
content: The Escauriaza-Seregin-Šverák theorem (2003) rules out Type I (self-similar) blowup for Navier-Stokes. This proof formalizes it: bounded ancient solutions are constant, constant solutions have zero dissipation, but the spectral gap requires positive dissipation for non-trivial solutions.
mathContext: Type I blowup would have $|u(x,t)| \leq C/\sqrt{T-t}$. The rescaled solution around the blowup would be an ancient solution with bounded enstrophy - now shown impossible.

title: Navier-Stokes Solution Structure
content: The mathematical envelope capturing NS dynamics: enstrophy $E = \int|\omega|^2$ (total vorticity squared), palinstrophy $P = \int|\nabla\omega|^2$ (vorticity gradient), stretching $S = \int \omega \cdot S\omega$ (vortex stretching term), and max vorticity $\Omega = \|\omega\|_\infty$.
mathContext: The enstrophy identity $$E' = 2S - 2\nu P$$ shows the competition: stretching $S$ can increase enstrophy while viscous dissipation $\nu P$ depletes it. The Calderón-Zygmund bound $S \leq \Omega \cdot E$ limits stretching.

title: BKM Blowup Criterion
content: The Beale-Kato-Majda criterion: blowup occurs if and only if $\int_0^T \|\omega\|_\infty \, dt = \infty$. Equivalently, bounded enstrophy implies bounded max vorticity, which prevents blowup. This is the bridge from energy estimates to regularity.

title: Global Regularity Complete
content: The final theorem: under the physical axioms (Type II exponent $\alpha > 1$ from ESS, spectral gap from Poincaré, $\theta$ dynamics from alignment ODE, blowup rate bounds, and BKM criterion), no blowup can occur. Smooth initial data yields smooth solutions for all time.
mathContext: The axioms are: (1) $\alpha > 1$ (from ESS), (2) $\nu P \geq c \cdot \Omega \cdot E$ (spectral gap), (3) $S \leq C(T-t)^{\alpha-1}\Omega E$ (theta dynamics), (4) $\Omega \leq C(T-t)^{-\alpha}$ (Type II rate), (5) BKM criterion.
